Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Highly unsaturated fatty acid transfer from aquatic to terrestrial food webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Streams depend upon nutrients from terrestrial landscapes to fuel the production of the plants and animals living in them. Reciprocally, stream organisms such as emerging aquatic insects provide energy and nutrients to terrestrial predators, including streamside birds. Emergent stream insects are likely an especially important food source for streamside predators. Most past studies on nutrient movement between streams and terrestrial landscapes have been conducted in relatively undisturbed forests. However, the contribution of stream-derived nutrients to streamside predators may actually be less important in forested streams than in highly productive streams in agricultural landscapes where algae and stream insects are abundant. This research will examine effects of: 1) food availability and quality on the growth rates of a representative streamside bird, the Eastern Phoebe (Sayornis phoebe), and 2) agricultural versus forested land use on the availability and quality of freshwater and terrestrial food resources for Eastern Phoebe chicks. The researchers will collaborate with local environmental managers and landowners by sharing summaries of results, and at publicly accessible study sites, informational signs will be used to explain the research. The researchers will work with a local children's science museum to develop presentations based on the research themes, and will continue to mentor underrepresented minority undergraduates.

Effects of food quality and quantity will be measured by raising phoebe chicks during their most rapid period of growth (days 4-9) in lab settings. Chicks will be fed diets that vary in quantity (high or low calorie) and quality (high or low highly unsaturated fatty acids) in a two by two design. Phoebe chick weight, head length, and tarsus length will be measured daily. To examine the effects of land use on food quality and quality in a natural setting, chick growth measurements will be coupled to fatty acid composition analyses to quantify food quality across sites. Stable isotope analyses of phoebe tissues and their terrestrial and aquatic dietary items will be used to reconstruct where phoebes obtain food resources. The researchers expect agricultural sites to provide phoebes with both higher food quantity and quality resulting in faster phoebe growth rates. Compound-specific stable isotope analyses of phoebe tissues and their terrestrial and aquatic dietary items will be performed to determine how land use affects where phoebes obtain highly unsaturated fatty acids. The researchers expect phoebes at agricultural sites to obtain highly unsaturated fatty acids synthesized by aquatic primary producers and phoebes at forested sites to obtain highly unsaturated fatty acids elongated from their molecular precursors synthesized by terrestrial primary producers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Streams depend upon nutrient inputs from terrestrial landscapes to fuel the production of the plants and animals living in them. Reciprocally, stream organisms such as emerging aquatic insects provide energy and nutrients to terrestrial predators, including streamside birds. Emergent aquatic insects are likely an especially important food source for streamside predators because stream insects are rich in highly unsaturated fatty acids (HUFAs), essential organic nutrients that all animals need to grow and develop. Most past studies on nutrient movement between streams and terrestrial landscapes have been conducted in relatively undisturbed forests even though streamside birds live in a variety of landscapes.

This research examined: 1) the effects of food availability and quality on the growth rates of two representative streamside birds, the Eastern Phoebe (Sayornis phoebe) and the Tree Swallow (Tachycineta bicolor), 2) the ability of streamside birds to convert HUFA precursors into HUFA,  3) whether aquatic or terrestrial food resources are richer in HUFA, and 4) how agricultural versus forested land use impact the quality of terrestrial and aquatic food resources and sources of HUFAs for streamside birds. In conducting this research, the researchers collaborated with local environmental managers and landowners by sharing results and full manuscripts as requested and by presenting research in seminars open to the public. The researchers also mentored three female underrepresented STEM minority undergraduates.

            Effects of food quality in terms of HUFA were measured by raising swallow and phoebe chicks during their most rapid period of growth (days 4-9) in lab settings. HUFA significantly improved growth and body condition (a strong predictor of survival in the wild) in both swallow and phoebe chicks. Food quality in terms of HUFA was also compared to food availability in swallow chicks in a two by two design. Small amounts of food high in HUFA improved growth and body condition more than large amounts of food lower in HUFA and the HUFA content of food boosted immunocompetence as much as a high quantity of food in swallow chicks. 

To determine whether aquatic or terrestrial food resources were richer in HUFA in nature and to examine the effects of land use on food quality and quality in a natural setting, fatty acid composition analyses were performed to quantify food quality across sites. The fatty acid composition of food resources did not vary predictably with land use. Across all sites, aquatic food resources (freshwater insects and algae) were significantly richer in HUFA than terrestrial food resources (fully terrestrial insects and leaves). Across sites, terrestrial resources were as rich or even richer than aquatic resources in the HUFA precursor. 

The importance of HUFA versus their precursor was assessed by feeding wild swallow chicks the precursor to HUFA and analyzing the efficiency with which they converted it to HUFA. Swallow chicks were able to convert the HUFA precursor into small amounts of HUFA, but with their efficiency was too low for them to be able to rely on the precursor alone. Coupled with the results from the lab experiment and fatty acid composition data, this shows that HUFA-rich aquatic insects are a vital food resource for growing streamside birds. Supporting this, the researchers also analyzed 30 years worth of data from a swallow breeding site and found that aquatic insects, but not terrestrial insects, were the strongest predictor of chick survival in the wild.

Stable isotope analyses of phoebe tissues and their terrestrial and aquatic dietary items were used to reconstruct where phoebes obtain food resources in the wild. Compound-specific stable isotope analyses of phoebe tissues and their terrestrial and aquatic dietary items were performed to determine how land use affects where phoebes obtain HUFAs. Across sites, phoebes obtained HUFAs synthesized by aquatic algae regardless of where they obtained food in general. This shows that even small amounts of aquatic insects can provide vital nutrients for insect-eating birds.
